title: AB 332
content: The State of California enacts the following. Recent public opinion research in California shows that residents are concerned about the costs of growing older, particularly in affording long-term care. Two-thirds of respondents worry about being able to pay for long-term care, with a majority unable to afford more than three months of nursing home care. Concerns about paying for long-term care are widespread across income levels and political affiliations, with many Latino voters lacking long-term care insurance. The Legislature aims to establish a task force to explore creating a culturally competent statewide insurance program for long-term care services. The Long Term Care Insurance Task Force will be created in the Department of Insurance to design and implement the program, consisting of nine members including the commissioner and representatives from relevant departments appointed by the Governor. The Long Term Care Insurance Task Force will consist of nine members appointed by the Governor, including the Director of Health Care Services, the Director of the Department of Aging, and representatives from various backgrounds such as actuarial, health policy, long-term care provider association, and senior or consumer organizations. Additionally, there will be a member from an employee representative organization and the long-term care insurance industry. Task force members will not receive compensation, and meetings will be subject to the Bagley-Keene Open Meeting Act. The Long Term Care Insurance Task Force, consisting of nine members appointed by the Governor, will explore the design and implementation of a statewide long-term care insurance program. This program aims to provide options for individuals seeking coverage for costs related to functional or cognitive disability, long-term care services, and supports. The task force will consider various aspects of the program, including eligibility, benefits, financing, and interaction with publicly funded resources like Medi-Cal. The Long Term Care Insurance Task Force is exploring the inclusion of a long-term care insurance program in the state disability insurance structure. This program would allow working adults to enroll voluntarily and receive basic insurance benefits for long-term care needs. Mandatory enrollment with a voluntary opt-out option may be required, aiming to help individuals with functional or cognitive limitations stay in their communities by purchasing nonmedical services and supports. The Long Term Care Insurance Task Force is considering a program to help individuals with chronic conditions by purchasing nonmedical services and supports. They also aim to evaluate benefits coordination with existing private health care coverage, address the demands on the long-term care workforce, and establish a joint public and private system for long-term care accessibility in California. The Long Term Care Insurance Task Force in California is considering establishing a joint public and private system to make long-term care accessible. They also plan to make recommendations for regulatory provisions for accessing existing and future long-term care insurance programs. The department and governmental agencies involved will operate within their existing budgetary resources. The task force will recommend options for a statewide long-term care insurance program in a report due by July 1, 2017. The department will produce an actuarial report by July 1, 2018, based on the task force's recommendations. The commissioner may seek private funds for implementation. The commissioner may seek private funds for implementing this section, which will be in effect until January 1, 2019, unless extended by a later statute enacted before that date.
